background: Recent publication suggest that domestication may cause a tradeoff such that families that perform well in the hatchery (produced many surviving adult offspring), produce offspring that have lowered reproductive success in the wild (Christie et al., 2012; Ford et al., 2012). Circumstantial evidence in Christie et al. (2012) suggest that crowding enhances the rate of domestication, and therefore that fish may be adapting to high crowding levels. If true, one prediction is that the rank performance of families (growth rate) depends on the density at which they were raised (i.e families that do best at low density do worst at high, and vice versa).
title: growth rate of juvenile hatchery fish
assumptions: Juvenile growth rate is assumed to be a component of total fitness because size at release is correlated with subsequent survival.
objectives: Test for presence of significant family by environment (crowding level) interaction in fish raised in a hatchery
